description: Lithuania has introduced a state emergency status to make preventive steps against the possible arrival and spread of the virus.
Lithuanian Foreign Ministry advises Lithuanian citizens against travelling to China until the spread of the coronavirus has been contained.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Lithuania's borders are closed from 16 March - 13 April, to both inbound and outbound persons, with exceptions for delivery trucks, diplomats, etc. UPDATE: Originally, Lithuania closed its borders from 13-30 March, but on 27 March it was announced that this policy would be extended until 13 April
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 9 April it was announced that Lithuania has extended its border closure, now lasting from 13 March to 27 April. This means that all foreigners will be banned from entering the country unless they are crossing through to travel to their home countries. UPDATE: In Lithuania, the original quarantine was set to be from 16-30 March, then it was extended to 13 April, and now it's extended to 27 April.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From 16-30 March, Lithuania closes its borders to all people coming in and out, with exceptions for delivery drivers, diplomats, etc.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 19, several mobile coronavirus testing sites opened on Thursday in Vilnius and Kaunas (areas most affected by corona at this point). More are to be launched in other towns across the country.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 7 April, the Parliament of Lithuania approved a pay rise of 60–100 percent for healthcare workers, including medical residents, working in coronavirus hotspots during the lockdown. Respective amendments to the Law on Prevention and Control of Communicable Diseases in Humans were passed unanimously with 120 votes in favour. The salaries of medical workers working in the hotspots of highly dangerous communicable diseases would increase by 60 to 100 per cent. The pay rise would be financed from the national budget, instead of the Compulsory Health Insurance Fund.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 8 April it was announced that Lithuania has allocated medical devices worth 100,000 euros to Italy and Spain. The prime minister said the funds would be used to buy essential devices produced in Lithuania, including protective shields, respirators, as well as medical equipment use to maintain the breathing function.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Announced 8 April and starting 10 April, it will be mandatory to wear facemasks in public in Lithuania. Up until now, it has been only recommended to do so. The Seimas of Lithuania earlier increased fines for people flouting quarantine requirement and they now face fines ranging from 500 to 1,000 euros. Executives of legal entities or other responsible person will face fines ranging from 1,500 to 6,000 euros.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 27 April 2020, a plane from the Spanish Air Force took off from the Lithuanian Air Force Base near Šiauliai (Lithuania) to deliver critical medical supplies to Spain, produced by Lithuania, as part of ongoing Allied efforts to contain the COVID-19 pandemic.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Lithuanian health specialists will consult people arriving from China and have been on standby at Lithuania's three airports.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From 10 April until 13 April, in Lithuania, people shall be restricted from going to the cities or towns of a municipality other than their place of residence, except the cases of the death of their close relatives or work, where the workplace is in another municipality, or urgent medical assistance.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: As of 13 March, Lithuania is on a partial-lockdown until at least 27 March
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On advisement of the country’s Ministry of Health, the government of Lithuania will be relaxing restrictions on leisure activities, travel (as of May 4), and will permit healthcare workers to resume regular services.
Lithuania sets up a State Emergency Operations Center, headed by Health Minister Aurelijus Veryga, to coordinate efforts against the spread of the COVID-19 virus
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: Lithuania's capital Vilnius held a 'Mask Fashion Week' to encourage and normalize the wearing of masks in all public spaces.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: The National Public Health Centers announced that people returning to Lithuania from China can claim 14 days sick leave and request temporary housing if they live with somebody else.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: To control the spread of coronavirus (COVID-19), the Government decided to declare quarantine on the entire territory of the Republic of Lithuania. The quarantine regime shall be effective from 16 March 2020, 00:00, until 30 March 2020, 24:00. UPDATE: The previous policy of a partial shutdown from 13-27 March has been expanded to a full national quarantine.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: March 12, Lithuania "People arriving from affected countries (Italy, France, Germany Spain, China, Hong Kong, Iran, Japan, South Korea and Singapore) will have to self-isolate for two weeks".
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: March 12, Lithuania "People arriving from affected countries (Italy, France, Germany Spain, China, Hong Kong, Iran, Japan, South Korea and Singapore) will have to self-isolate for two weeks".
type_sub_cat: Government Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at a government hotel or facility)
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: As of 25 March, the Lithuanian government requires people returning from any country abroad to self-isolate at home for 14 days, and if a person refuses, they will be forcibly quarantined in a municipal facility for 14 days. UPDATE: Originally, from 12-27 March, people returning to Lithuania from a specific list of corona-affected countries had to self-isolate at home. As of 25 March, the Lithuanian government requires people returning from any country abroad to self-isolate at home for 14 days, and if a person refuses, they will be forcibly quarantined in a municipal facilitiy.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: As of 24 April, the original quarantine/lockdown has been relaxed in order to allow limited church services. According to the Lithuanian Bishop's Conference, Roman Catholic churches in Lithuania will be able to celebrate Masses with congregations, except on Sundays. Believers will not be allowed into churches without face masks and a density of one person per 10 square meters will have to be ensured. If the church cannot accommodate all of the faithful, those who remain outdoors will have to stand two meters from each other. UPDATE: The original quarantine/lockdown, which started on 13 March and was strengthened on 16 March, has been relaxed in order to allow limited church services.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: As of 27 April, Lithuania's government is relaxing the lockdown to allow hops, open-air restaurants and many other services to reopen. Shops and mall, customer service businesses, such as hairdressers, libraries, museums and golf courses, can also reopen. Businesses will need to limit numbers of customers on their premises to no more than one person per 10 square meters. A full lift of lockdown measures has been delayed to 11 May. UPDATE: Lithuania went into lockdown starting 13 March, and as of 27 April the government is relaxing this lockdown.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Lithuania's government recommends avoiding mass events over the coronavirus. Government representatives also advise people in risk groups to avoid mass events.
Lithuania’s government recommended cancelling mass events in the northern city of Siauliai where the country's first case of corona was detected.

As of 24 March, stricter measures are imposed on all grocery stores in Lithuania. All visitors should disinfect their hands at the points of entry, shopping trolleys and shopping bags should be cleaned and disinfected after each use. Plastic panels should be installed between cashiers and clients, other protective equipment to be provided. Distance between staff members is at least 2 meters. Visitors should be encouraged to pay by cards. Ban on shopping in supermarkets for more than 2 individuals at a time comes into effect, family members have to go shopping by one.

On 27 March passenger carriers, transport organizers and passengers adopted security measures to reduce the number of carried passengers.

Passenger carriers have been ordered to limit the number of carried passengers. For example, buses are allowed to carry no more than 50% of passengers the bus has seats for.
Carriers also have to ensure the driver is distanced from passengers and perform regular disinfection of the interior of the vehicle.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart

Lithuania’s capital, Vilnius, has announced plans to turn the city into a vast open-air cafe by giving over much of its public space to bar and restaurant owners so they can put their tables outdoors and still observe physical distancing rules.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
